content.text: Solutions A and B consisting of calcium hydroxide dissolved in water. <image 1> Solution A is a calcium hydroxide solution that has a concentration of 0.350 M and a volume of 500. mL. What mass of calcium hydroxide was dissolved to make this solution? (Note: The molar mass of calcium hydroxide is 74.093 g/mol.)

To find the mass of calcium hydroxide dissolved in Solution A, we can use the formula:

\[ \text{Mass} = \text{Concentration} \times \text{Volume} \times \text{Molar Mass} \]

Given:
- Concentration of calcium hydroxide in Solution A = 0.350 M
- Volume of Solution A = 500 mL
- Molar mass of calcium hydroxide = 74.093 g/mol

First, we need to convert the volume from mL to L because the concentration is given in M ( (mol/L):

\[ 500 \text{ mL} = 500 \text{ mL} \times \frac{1 \text{ L}}{1000 \text{ mL}} = 0.5 \text{ L} \]

Now we can calculate the mass:

\[ \text{Mass} = 0.350 \text{ M} \times 0.5 \text{ L} \times 74.093 \text{ g/mol} \]

\[ \text{Mass} = 0.350 \times 0.5 \times 74.093 \]

\[ \text{Mass} = 12.726 \text{ g} \]

So, the mass of calcium hydroxide dissolved to make Solution A is approximately 12.726 g.
